body: Perplexity只是用来打印收敛情况而已，并不是用来控制网络运行的损失函数，即便没有Perplexity网络运行也照旧，不知道@piiswrong 为何得此结论“Perplexity used to be calculated in numpy, which is slow”？

can u explain a bit more what feature you are trying to achieve? and what's blocking you to do it in C/C++ using nnvm api?
It seems to be a GNU STL library problem. I rebuilded standalone toolchain with libc++ and compiled successfully.

I believe I could do it C/C++ since this functionality has to exist to do autodiff and graph plotting and the tojson method visible in Python, but I would like it to be part of the Python API because that's what I'm coding in for my projects.

Here is a simple example. Suppose some client code created a simple MLP:

```
data = mx.sym.Variable('data')
fc1 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=data, name='fc1', num_hidden=100)
act1 = mx.sym.Activation(data=fc1, name='act1', act_type='relu')
fc2 = mx.sym.FullyConnected(data=act1, name='fc2', num_hidden=10)
out = mx.sym.SoftmaxOutput(data=fc2)
```

Then we have some host code we're writing that will receive a symbol. In this case, out. What I would like to be able to do, is from that single symbol received determine what the input symbols are. If I call list_arguments() on out, what it will give me is data and the labels, because those are the variables in the graph. But I want the input symbols; that is, I want it a minimum to return me fc2 (and the internally created softmax labels symbol). And if it returns me fc2, that means I could similarly query it for its input symbols, which would return act1; and so on.

Being able to explore the symbol graph, along with reflection, facilitates programmatic adaptation of graphs. Here's one possible way I might use that. Suppose I have a non standard RNN structure (not LSTM or the usual layers). With the ability to explore the graph, I could create a function that took an arbitrary zero-time step graph with a specification of any cyclic edges and have it automatically unroll the graph to an arbitrary time horizon. But there are other things that could be done too.

If it can be useful for some R users in the meantime, I've put compiled binaries that should work with R 3.3 on windows: 
`install.packages("https://github.com/jeremiedb/mxnet_winbin/raw/master/mxnet.zip", repos = NULL)
`

A bit off subject, but I wonder if there were already some plan to some plans to provide further helpers in R such as bucketing or the multi-threaded mx.image? I could take a look at bucketing to refresh LSTM example, I also noticed the for loop approach for building dictionnary is much less efficient in R than the vectorized approach. Thanks!

I know there are lots of work need to be done on R APIs. But as a PhD student, I really don't have much time now.

If you have any suggestion or requirement, please just open an issue. I will close as many issues as possible during my internship this summer.

Hello everyone,
I managed to compile mxnet 0.9.3 on galaxy 2 tablet. I had to change the folowing part of the config.mk (add armv8l in the processor list) : 
#----------------------------
# Settings for power and arm arch
#----------------------------
ARCH := $(shell uname -a)
ifneq (,$(filter $(ARCH), armv6l armv7l armv8l powerpc64le ppc64le aarch64))
        USE_SSE=0
else
...

Hope it will help.

Thanks to everyone involved.  I teach machine learning for social
scientists, and despite my preference for Python, R remains the easiest
environment to use for people coming from the SAS/Stata world.

MXNET is by far the best deep learning tool out there.  You are to be
congratulated on your endeavor.

@janelu9, sorry for the late reply.
For distributed training, you need to compile with `USE_DIST_KVSTORE=1`, since this option is false for official docker image, that's why you need to build it by yourself.

@piiswrong , i came across a problem like this:
```
File "/data0/anaconda2/lib/python2.7/site-packages/mxnet-0.7.0-py2.7.egg/mxnet/optimizer.py", line 817, in update
    weight[:] = -(z - (z>0) * self.lamda1 + (z < 0) * self.lamda1) / ((self.beta + sqrt(n))/self.alpha + self.lamda2)(z > self.lamda1) 
TypeError: 'NDArray' object is not callable
```


My implemention is as followed:
`@register
class Ftrl(Optimizer):

    def __init__(self, lamda1=0.90, lamda2=0.90, alpha=0.1, beta=0.2, epsilon=1e-5, **kwargs):
        super(Ftrl, self).__init__(**kwargs)
        self.lamda1 = lamda1
        self.lamda2 = lamda2
        self.alpha = alpha
        self.beta = beta


    def create_state(self, index, weight):
        return (zeros(weight.shape, weight.context),  # sigma
                zeros(weight.shape, weight.context),  # z
                zeros(weight.shape, weight.context))  # n

    def update(self, index, weight, grad, state):
        assert(isinstance(weight, NDArray))
        assert(isinstance(grad, NDArray))
        wd = self._get_wd(index)
        self._update_count(index)

        # preprocess grad
        grad *= self.rescale_grad
        if self.clip_gradient is not None:
            grad = clip(grad, -self.clip_gradient, self.clip_gradient)

        # accumulated g and delta initlization
        sigma, z, n = state


        #update sigma, z, n
        sigma[:] = (sqrt(n + grad) -sqrt(n)) / self.alpha
        z[:] += grad - sigma * weight * wd
        n[:] += grad * grad

        # update weight
        weight[:] = -(z - (z>0) * self.lamda1 + (z < 0) * self.lamda1) / ((self.beta + sqrt(n))/self.alpha + self.lamda2)(z > self.lamda1)`

When launching worker and server nodes, they send a control message of `ADD_NODE` to the scheduler. The scheduler will know the whole information about worker and server nodes. It then send a response message of this information to each node.

Update. `image` is now supported. I'm going to make TensorBoard easy to install by `pip install tensorboard` in the next few weeks. Then try to finish the rest `audio`, `graph` and `embedding`, might need some time. 

As we've finished the `image`, the **visualization toolbox for MXNet** could be started, my plan is to support the common visualization techniques to understand the neural network, like CS231n does.  @piiswrong @mufeili

another problem:  when use operation z>0(type of z is ndarray), type of the result is  True or False, it's not ndarray type.
```

you can see visualization.py
```
def print_summary(symbol, shape=None, line_length=120, positions=[.44, .64, .74, 1.]):
...
interals = symbol.get_internals()
 _, out_shapes, _ = interals.infer_shape(**shape)
shape_dict = dict(zip(interals.list_outputs(), out_shapes))
```

The last two question:
1.  i know it need reload ndarray ‘>’ operation, where to implement
2.  i want to use u = (z.asnumpy()>0)*alpha + (z.asnumpy()<0)*beta, how to transform type numpy about u into ndarray.
tks, @piiswrong
@Godricly Thanks for your reply.  Could you tell me how to the input image to [-1.0, 1.0] ?

question 2 is solved as followed:
```
weight[:] = -(z - array((z.asnumpy() > 0) * self.lamda1 + (z.asnumpy() <= 0) * self.lamda1 * (-1))) / ((self.beta + sqrt(n))/self.alpha + self.lamda2) * array(abs(z).asnumpy() > self.lamda1)
```
The remaining questions are question 1 above.

```

There is a scale parameter in [mxnet.io.ImageRecordIter](http://mxnet.io/api/python/io.html) which u can rescale the intensity. you need to add this parameter to [this](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/image-classification/common/data.py) file if you are running the example. Also remember to subtract the mean before doing so. 
I think the label should be ok.

| cast | mean | bright | contrast | saturation | pca_noise | mirror | rand_crop | rand_pad | sample/s |

yes, eval_metric is used to report the model train accuracy rate, eval_metric doesn't influence the model training. I also don't know how to define loss lay. I doesn't know what loss function on the Softmax lay.
Because softmax_label is the default name of data iterator's output **Unless you define a data iterator**

Suppose we train 1 epoch, the first run would be --begin_epoch 0 and the checkpoint from epoch 0 is saved as prefix-0001.params. Now we want to resume from the checkpoint from epoch 0, as is in the doc, we should specify begin_epoch as 0+1 which is 1. So we load prefix-0001.params. Everything works.
In other words, don't forget epoch 0 and in your case after 3 epoch, you should resume from 3 (3 is the fourth if you start from 0, right?). Therefore I find this change unfit to the module convention.
KVScheduler, KVWorker and KVServer are system processes in which a `van` instance runs as a rpc tool. `tracker.py` is just to launch those processes.
